sub_topic: Show that every group of order 32 is isomorphic to either the cyclic group C32, the dihedral group D16, or one of the six non-abelian groups of order 32.
message_1: Consider a group G of order 32. If the group G has an element of order 32, then it is isomorphic to the cyclic group C32. If G has no element of order 32, but has an element of order 16, then it is isomorphic to the dihedral group D16. Determine which non-abelian group of order 32 G is isomorphic to, if G does not have an element of order 16 or 32.
message_2:
If G does not have an element of order 16 or 32, then the maximum order of any element in G must be 8. By Sylow's Theorems, we know that G has a subgroup of order 8, say H. Since H is a subgroup of order 8, it must be isomorphic to either C8 (cyclic group of order 8) or D8 (dihedral group of order 8).

Now, let's consider the normalizer N of H in G. Since H is a subgroup of G, we have H ⊆ N. By the definition of the normalizer, we know that N is the largest subgroup of G in which H is normal. Since H is normal in N, we can form the quotient group N/H. The order of N/H divides the order of G/H, which is 32/8 = 4. Thus, N/H is either isomorphic to C4 (cyclic group of order 4) or C2 × C2 (Klein-4 group).

If N/H is isomorphic to C4, then N is isomorphic to H × C4, which is a group of order 32. In this case, G = N, and G is isomorphic to C8 × C4, which is an abelian group. This contradicts the assumption that G is non-abelian.

If N/H is isomorphic to C2 × C2, then N is isomorphic to H × (C2 × C2), which is a group of order 16. In this case, G is an extension of N by a group of order 2. By the Schreier's Theorem, there exists a non-abelian group G of order 32 such that G has a normal subgroup N of order 16 and G/N is isomorphic to C2.

This non-abelian group G of order 32 is called the Quaternion group of order 32, denoted by Q32. Therefore, if G does not have an element of order 16 or 32, G is isomorphic to the Quaternion group Q32.
